did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Pamphlets, many rare and original, some photocopies, primarily regarding African American History. Some pamphlets are directly related to the Prudence Crandall story, while others are only related thematically. The focus of the Prudence Crandall Library is African American History, Slavery, Antislavery, Education, and Women's History. Most pamphlets date from the 19th century.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the The Prudence Crandall Museum.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], The Prudence Crandall Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Random sample of pamphlets in the Pamphlet Collection are as follows:
A Narrative of the Adventures and Escape of Moses Roper from American Slavery. Isaac Knapp, publisher, 1838.
The African Captives: Trial of the Prisoners of the Amistad on the writ of Habeas Corpus: Thompson and Judson, 1839.
The Extension of Slavery: The Official Acts of both parties to the People of Connecticut, Connecticut Democratic Party, 1856.
The Negro in the Abolitionist Movement., Apthecker, Herbert, 1941.
Life of James Mars, A Slave Born and Sold in Connecticut. Mars, James, 1868.
School Fellow Magazine for Boys and Girls, Miller and Curtis, publishers, 1857.
Cobblestone, The History Magazine for young people. Cobblestone, publisher, 1983.
Heroes, A Look at Black History in Connecticut., White, David O., 1986.
A Gamut, or a Scale of Music., Cook and Hale, publishers, 1816.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Pamphlets are arranged chronologically in the Pamphlet File cabinet drawer.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.title: Boston Slave Riot and the Trial of Anthony Burns
Conference Hyms Selected from Various Authors for the Use of the Pious of Every Denomination
The Role of Local History
The Development of Education in Africa and its Problems
The Re-Captured Negro
New England Anti-Slavery Convention of 1836
controlaccess.subject: Slavery
African Americans - History
